    Overview

    Depending on your income, you may need to pay towards the cost of the work to the property.

    if income_high: may_need_to_pay_towards_cost = True #

#

Standard route

#

Apply by the standard route if all the following are true:

if standard_route_eligibility: #
  • you’re 18 or over
    • age_over_18 = True #
  • you’ve been diagnosed with gender dysphoria (discomfort with your birth gender) - this is also called gender identity disorder, gender incongruence or transsexualism
    • diagnosed_with_gender_dysphoria = True #
  • you’ve lived in your acquired gender for at least 2 years
    • lived_in_acquired_gender_for_2_years = True #
  • you intend to live in your acquired gender for the rest of your life

    Alternative route

#

As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.

#

A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.

#

You could get time off when a dependant is involved in the following emergencies.

#

Illness, injury or assault

#

This includes mental or physical illnesses that don’t have to be life-threatening or need full-time care - it could be an existing condition that has worsened.

#

For example, if a dependant is mugged without being physically hurt, you could take time off to comfort or help them.

#

You can also take time off to arrange longer term care for a dependant.

# Document: #

Overview

#

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

#
  • employment conditions
    • #
  • rights
    • #
  • responsibilities
    • #
  • duties
    • employment_contract = True #

    These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    terms_of_contract = True #

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    contract_valid_until_end_or_changed = True #

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    contract_to_provide_services = True #

    Contract terms

    #

    The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

    legal_parts_of_contract = True #

    Contract terms could be:

    #
  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
    • #
  • verbally agreed
    • #
  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
    • #
  • in an offer letter from the employer
    • #
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
    • #
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
    • #
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • if in_written_contract or verbally_agreed or in_employee_handbook or on_company_notice_board or in_offer_letter or required_by_law or in_collective_agreements or implied_terms: contract_terms = True

# Document: #

Your rights

#

As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.

allowed_time_off_for_emergency_involving_dependant = True #

A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.

dependant_categories = ["spouse", "partner", "child", "grandchild", "parent", "someone who depends on you for care"] #

How much you get

#

You’re allowed a reasonable amount of time off to deal with the emergency, but there’s no set amount of time as it depends on the situation.

reasonable_amount_of_time_off_allowed = True #

Tell your employer as soon as possible how much time you’ll need so it can be agreed.

tell_employer_time_needed_for_agreement = True #

What's an emergency?

#

You could get time off when a dependant is involved in the following emergencies.

#

Illness, injury or assault

#

This includes mental or physical illnesses that don’t have to be life-threatening or need full-time care - it could be an existing condition that has worsened.

illness_injury_or_assault_emergency = True #

For example, if a dependant is mugged without being physically hurt, you could take time off to comfort or help them.

example_situation_mugging_without_physical_harm = True #

You can also take time off to arrange longer term care for a dependant.

take_time_off_to_arrange_long_term_care = True

inter_results.full_response:
#

If you do not consult employees in a redundancy situation, any redundancies you make will almost certainly be unfair and you could be taken to an employment tribunal.

#

You must follow ‘collective consultation’ rules if you’re making 20 or more employees redundant within any 90-day period at a single establishment.

#

There are no set rules to follow if there are fewer than 20 redundancies planned, but it’s good practice to fully consult employees and their representatives. An employment tribunal could decide that you’ve dismissed your staff unfairly if you do not.

#

Consultation does not have to end in agreement, but it must be carried out with a view to reaching it, including ways of avoiding or reducing the redundancies.

# Answer: no

    if limited_company_setup: different_reporting_dates = True #

    You started trading the day your company set up

    if started_trading_same_day_as_setup: file_2_tax_returns = True #

    Example

    Prepare your first set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for 11 May 2013 to 10 May 2014
    • #
  • second tax return for 11 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your accounts and tax returns will normally cover your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May.

    if prepare_first_accounts and file_first_tax_return and file_second_tax_return: accounts_and_tax_returns_cover_financial_year = True #

    Example

    Prepare accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file one tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014.

#

For less than 12 months

#

You must take your vehicle log book (V5C) with you if you’re taking your vehicle abroad for less than 12 months. You may have to show it if you’re stopped at a port or while driving abroad.

#

Your V5C must show your most recent address in the UK.

#

UK law still applies to a UK-registered vehicle if you take it abroad for less than 12 months. That means you need to make sure:

#
  • your vehicle is taxed in the UK while it’s abroad
    • #
  • you have a current MOT
    • #
  • you have insurance
    • #

    You’ll also need to make sure you meet any international or national conditions for licensing and taxation.

Yes, you can challenge your A level results. #

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

#

You can challenge the result of a GCSE, AS level or A level exam.

# Answer: Yes, you can challenge your A level results. #

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

#

Apply to the Gender Recognition Panel for a Gender Recognition Certificate if you want your acquired gender to be legally recognised in the UK.

  • contact your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales
    • #
  • contact the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland (EONI) if you live in Northern Ireland
    • # Answer: yes
